newsitem.title: USA: Conn. utility industry needs revamp -atty general.
newsitem.headline: Conn. utility industry needs revamp -atty general.

text.p: A scathing state audit report on Northeast Utilities shows the need for a total restructuring of electric utilities in Connecticut, state attorney general Richard Blumenthal said Tuesday.

"This very scathing audit demonstrates the need for additional competition and restructuring at Northeast Utilities and in our electric industry in general," Blumenthal said in comments broadcast on local radio.

He was responding to a report issued earlier Tuesday by Connecticut's Department of Public Utility Control (DPUC), which concluded that Northeast and its subsidiary mismanaged the state's four nuclear units over the last decade.
Blumenthal said that increased competition would provide ratepayers with cheaper and more reliable service. He did not elaborate.

"This scathing audit of the management of Connecticut's four nuclear plants is further evidence that the troubles with Connecticut's nuclear plants are the result of massive mismanagement at Northeast Utilities," Blumenthal also said in a statement issued Tuesday.
"The costs associated with this nuclear mismanagement will be the responsibility of Northeast Utilities and not the citizens and businesses of Connecticut," he said.
The DPUC report said, "As NU has consistently misunderstood the nature of its problems over the past decade, it has consistently applied the wrong solutions."

Northeast and Connecticut Light and Power Co (CL&P) co-own and operate the 582 megawatt (MW) Connecticut Yankee generating station in Haddam Neck and three units, with combined capacity of nearly 2,700 MW, at the Millstone complex in Waterford.
The latest criticism of Northeast and CL&P followed a DPUC report earlier this month, which listed deficiencies and suggested technical improvements at each plant.
"It (The first report) was more technical, and this is more historical with the management and the NRC (Nuclear Regulatory Commission)," said DPUC spokeswoman Beryl Lyons.
